articles.headline: Navy Recruits Face a Hardship Test at the Airport
articles.snippet: Navy recruits on the way to boot camp have joined thousands of other travelers stranded as American Airlines cancels flights.
articles.abstract: Navy recruits on the way to boot camp have joined thousands of other travelers stranded as American Airlines cancels flights.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS  On Monday, Karin Peyregne was in Mobile, Ala., kissing her husband and two young sons goodbye, on her way to a base near Chicago for basic training in the Navy.
articles.byline: By Jeff Bailey and Marina Trahan Martinez

articles.headline: The Face of a Prophet
articles.snippet: George Soros has always been a controversial figure. But he is becoming more so with a new, dire forecast for the world economy.
articles.abstract: George Soros has always been a controversial figure. But he is becoming more so with a new, dire forecast for the world economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: George Soros will not go quietly.

articles.headline: House Votes to Put Off Trade Deal Bush Sought
articles.snippet: The unity exhibited Thursday by House Democrats in stalling a White House-sponsored trade pact with Colombia masks deep party divisions on the issue.
articles.abstract: The unity exhibited Thursday by House Democrats in stalling a White House-sponsored trade pact with Colombia masks deep party divisions on the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The unity exhibited Thursday by House Democrats in stalling a White House-sponsored trade pact with Colombia masks deep party divisions on the issue, which is certain to become even more highly charged given coming consequential trade deals with South Korea and other countries.

articles.headline: Abuse Trails Central American Girls Into Gangs
articles.snippet: Girls who join the ranks of Central America’s street gangs straddle the line between victims and victimizers.
articles.abstract: Girls who join the ranks of Central America’s street gangs straddle the line between victims and victimizers.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY  To join one of Central America’s fierce street gangs, Benky, a tiny young woman with heavy mascara and tattoos running up and down her arms, had to have sex with a dozen or so of her homeboys one night. She recalls sobbing uncontrollably when the last young man climbed off her and everyone gathered around to congratulate her on becoming a full-fledged member of the Mara Salvatrucha.

articles.headline: Couric’s Fate Was Topic A in CBS Suite
articles.snippet: A discussion in February about Katie Couric’s future as the anchor of the “CBS Evening News” threatened on Thursday to turn her into a virtual lame duck in the job.
articles.abstract: A discussion in February about Katie Couric’s future as the anchor of the “CBS Evening News” threatened on Thursday to turn her into a virtual lame duck in the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: A wide-ranging discussion in February about Katie Couric’s future as the anchor of the “CBS Evening News” threatened on Thursday to turn her into a virtual lame duck in the job.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Jacques Steinberg

articles.headline: From Welfare Shift in ’96, a Reminder for Clinton
articles.snippet: The issue of welfare policy is back, pulled to the fore by an economy turning down more sharply than at any other time since changes were imposed in 1996.
articles.abstract: The issue of welfare policy is back, pulled to the fore by an economy turning down more sharply than at any other time since changes were imposed in 1996.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1996, President Bill Clinton delivered on his pledge to “end welfare as we know it.” Despite howls of protest from some liberals, he signed into law a bill forcing recipients to work and imposing a five-year limit on cash assistance.

articles.headline: It’s a Crisis, and Ideas Are Scarce
articles.snippet: Paul Volcker says financial engineers have “produced unimaginable wealth for some, while repeatedly risking a cascading breakdown of the system as a whole.”
articles.abstract: Paul Volcker says financial engineers have “produced unimaginable wealth for some, while repeatedly risking a cascading breakdown of the system as a whole.”
articles.lead_paragraph: As the credit crisis has slowly expanded and worsened, there has been a flurry of activity in Washington to reduce the damage from it. There are bailouts and tax breaks, and even checks to parents of school-age children.

articles.headline: As Militias Roam Alleys, Iraqi Army Takes Brunt
articles.snippet: American commanders see the struggle for control of Sadr City, the stronghold of Shiite militias, as an opportunity to shift more responsibility to the Iraqis.
articles.abstract: American commanders see the struggle for control of Sadr City, the stronghold of Shiite militias, as an opportunity to shift more responsibility to the Iraqis.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi soldiers pushed their way up a main thoroughfare in Sadr City over the past week, but the militias that still prowl the Shiite enclave were sniping at them from the alleyways.

articles.headline: Creative Spots, Courtesy of a Stalled Economy
articles.snippet: Since the fall, many marketers have been appealing to worried consumers by acknowledging that times are tough.
articles.abstract: Since the fall, many marketers have been appealing to worried consumers by acknowledging that times are tough.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forget the fancy blandishments of Madison Avenue. An e-mail message sent on Thursday to advertise B. R. Guest Restaurants gets right to the point.
